div.head: I. Sanskrit
div.p: śṛnānatīti śrāvaka (śṛṇvantīti śrāvakāḥ ?)
They hear, hence they are Śrāvakas (‘Hearers’)
samyakajñāna pha lan śrā ba sintā ti śrāvaka ( samyagjñānaphalaṁ śrāvayantīti śrāvakāḥ ?)
They make others hear about the result of perfect awareness, thus they are Śrāvakas. (Trns. Mattia Salvini)
Saddharmapuṇḍarīkasūtra
kecit sattvāḥ paraghoṣaśravānugamanam ākāṅkṣamānā […] te ucyante śrāvakayānam ākāṅkṣamāṇāḥ (Kern and Nanjio, Saddharmapuṇḍarīka, p. 80.5).
Some sentient beings, wishing to follow what they hear from someone else’s voice […] are explained as those who wish for the Śrāvakayāna. (Trns. Mattia Salvini)
Arthaviniścayasūtranibandhana of Vīryaśrīdatta

bhagavato buddhasya pareṇa śrāvyanta iti śrāvakāḥ (N.H. Samtani (ed.), The Arthaviniścaya-sūtra & its Commentary (Nibandhana) (Patna: K.P. Jayaswal Research Institute, 1971 [Tibetan Sanskrit Works Series XIII])
Śrāvakas are so called because they are subsequently (pareṇa) brought to hear [the teaching] of the Buddha, the Blessed One.
N.H. Samtani (tr.) Gathering the Meanings: The Compendium of Categories: The Arthaviniścaya sūtra and its Commentary Nibandhana (Berkeley: Dharma Publishing, 2002), p. 182.
Of the Bhavagat, the Buddha, they are made to hear by someone else, thus they are “śrāvakas” (Trns. Mattia Salvini)
Vinayavastu
Eṣāgrā me bhikṣavo bhikṣuṇīnāṁ mama śrāvikāṇāṁ sūtrāntavibhāgakartrīṇāṁ yaduta kacaṁgalā bhikṣuṇī (Vinayavastu 132kha/1.21, Mithila Institute, Darbhanga, Bihar 1967)
This one, oh Bhikṣus, is the foremost amongst my Śrāvikās, who perform the subdivision of the Sūtrānta: Kacaṁgalā Bhikṣuṇī. (Trns. Mattia Salvini)

div.head: II. Tibetan

p.foreign: śrāvaka źes pa gcig tu na śṛnānatīti śrāvaka źes bya ste/ de bźin gśegs pa las chos kyi luṅ ma mnos par bdag ñid kyis rtogs par mi nus te ñan pa la yaṅ bya/ yaṅ gcig tu na samyakajñāna pha lan śrā ba sintā ti śrāvaka źes bya ste/ yaṅ dag pa’i śes pas rgyun du źugs pa la sogs pa’i ’bras bu thob pa gźan la sgrogs śiṅ thos par byed pas na ñan thos źes bya/

div.p: Because they are unable to realize by themselves without receiving the instruction of the Tathāgata , they are, for one, called “hearers” (nyan pa)....Or, in another way, because they proclaim and cause others to hear the fruits of a stream-enterer and so on that they have attained through correct knowledge, they are called “proclaimers who cause to be heard” (nyan thos). (Trns. David Rawson)
Saddharmapuṇḍarīkasūtra

p.foreign: mgon po de ring bdag cag nyan thos gyur/ /byang chub dam pa yang dag bsgrags par bgyi/ /byang chub pa yi sgra yang rab tu brjod/ /de bas bdag cag nyan thos mi zad 'dra

div.p:
Protector, today we have become proclaimers.
We proclaim perfect awakening.
We also express the sound of the awakened.
Because of that, we are 'proclaimers' who are similar to the inexhaustible.
(Trns. David Rawson)
Jayānanda’s subcommentary on the Madhyamakāvatārabhāṣya
byang chub dam pa bla na med pa yang dag par rdzogs pa'i byang chub gzhan gyis thos par byed pas nyan thos so (sde dge bstan 'gyur dbu ma vol ra F.No. 7.a)
Because someone else makes them hear of the perfect awakening, they are called “hearers.” (David Rawson)

div.head: III. Pāli
div.p: (All the Pāli passages are from the Chattha Saṅgāyana edition, unless otherwise specified)
Khuddakapāṭha-aṭṭhakathā, and also Suttanipāta-aṭṭhakathā
All of them hear the speech, thus they are “hearers” (Mattia Salvini)
Visuddhimagga of Buddhaghosa

bhagavato ovādānusāsaniṃ sakkaccaṃ suṇantī ti sāvakā (Henry Clarke Warren (ed.), revised by Dharmananda Kosambi, Visuddhimagga of Buddhaghosâcariya [1950] Repr. Motilal Banarsidass, Delhi, 1989 § 7.90. )
They are ‘listeners’ because they listen attentively to the instructions and teachings of the Fortunate One. (Peter Skilling)
Summary of the discussion

The Sanskrit term Śrāvaka, and its Tibetan and Pāli equivalents, are difficult to render in English with a single expression. The main difficulty is that we find at least three different possible etymologies in traditional sources:

item.p: 2. Active and causative (‘they make others hear’)
3. Passive and causative (‘they are made to hear by others’)

div.p: We may either retain the Sanskrit śrāvaka, or use one English term (as for example, ‘hearer’), or use different English renderings in different contexts.
